text: I thought I would share some of the main
reasons that we're finding why so many
customers are moving to the cloud and
why they're doing it so quickly and
there are a few benefits that we hear
frequently from customers that they
would cite as the most important reasons
the first thing is if you can trade
capital expense for variable expense
that's very attractive instead of having
to lay out all those all that capital
for data centers and servers before you
know how you're gonna use them and if
you don't have to do that instead just
pay as you consume resource on a
variable basis that's very appealing on
top of trading capital expense for
variable expense customers love the fact
in the cloud they get to pay a lower
variable expense that they could do on
their own and that's because AWS is able
to take it's very large scale and pass
those on to customers in the form of
lower prices and we have this very
interesting virtuous circle going on
which is as we have more customers who
use AWS more it means we have to go buy
more infrastructure but as we buy more
infrastructure we get economies of scale
which lower our infrastructure costs and
as we lower our infrastructure costs
we're able to lower our prices to
customers which drives more customers so
it's a very useful virtuous circle for
both customers and for AWS and then it
turns out that you can inject energy
into this flywheel so as we add new
services and new features and as we
expand our global footprint as we
continue to partner with our very large
and growing ecosystem so that more
companies can run the applications they
want to run on AWS and more companies
get help from systems integrators to
actually get moving to the cloud it
turns out that we're able to spin that
flywheel faster and as we're able to
continue to innovate on our
infrastructure so in our data centers
and on our network and with hardware
we're able to get better economies of
scale which lets us lower infrastructure
cause lower prices that again spin the
wheel going faster and you've seen this
bear out as we have lowered prices on 23
different occasions in the last few
years largely in the absence of
any competitive pressure to do so the
third thing that customers tell us that
they really like about the cloud is that
they don't have to guess on capacity
anymore so any of you that have tried to
launch a new project know that you have
to guess what your capacity is gonna be
and that's actually really hard to do
without knowing what the customer
response is and so what happens is you
end up making some projection
represented by the green dotted line and
the actual usage is often something like
the solid white line and what that means
is that in the beginning you actually
are sitting on a lot of wasted capital
and resource until your application
takes off and then if it does you're
left with too short
capacity and you either have to decide
to provide a bad customer experience
which most people don't choose or you
have to run around like a chicken with
your head cut off you can find somebody
who can get you that infrastructure
quickly and you almost always overpay
and over commit to do it in the cloud
that problem goes away you don't have to
guess you provision as much resource as
you think you need early on if it turns
out you need more you seamlessly scale
up if it turns out you don't need as
much as you provisioned at one point you
just give it back to us and stop paying
that's a very different model than the
last 30 years the fourth thing customers
tell us is that the cloud dramatically
improves how quickly they can get to
market with whatever applications
they're thinking about in the old world
if you if you talk to an engineer and an
enterprise or a company and you ask them
how long does it take you to provision a
server for something new or to put
something in in tag we got answers when
we ask customers this they range from 6
to 20 weeks that's maddening 6 to 20
weeks for a single server and what it
does is it just stifles innovation
people figure why bother if it's gonna
take so long just to get a server in the
cloud you can provision completely on
your own self-service you don't have to
talk to anybody hundreds or even
thousands of servers in minutes and that
really changes how quickly you can
deploy applications the two most
important things are number one being
able to try a lot of experiments and
number two
if those experiments don't work and many
of them should not work if you're really
pushing the envelope not to have to live
with the collateral damage of a failed
experiment and in the cloud you can spin
out thousands of instances in minutes so
you can try any experiments that you
guys as a team come up with and if they
don't work just give them back to us or
use them for other experiments you want
to try really changes the game and how
fast companies can move their businesses
forward the fifth thing we hear from
customers is that there's scarce
resource of most companies is software
development engineers engineering teams
have this long list of priorities and
projects that the company wants them to
do and you're left with this unpleasant
experience of having to try to
prioritize between them and those order
decisions are really specious they're
really hard to make the right ones we
know from the early days of Amazon it
was near impossible if you can take that
scarce resource who our software
development engineers and instead of
having them focus on the infrastructure
which is important but hardly ever
differentiates your business and instead
have them focused on projects that move
your mission or your business forward
that's a huge advantage the sixth thing
we hear from our customers is that they
like the fact that they can provide a
global high quality and user experience
all over the world so virtually every
company now even startups from day one
given the nature of the Internet in the
mobile world we live in have global
end-users and so in the old world people
would store their applications or run
their applications in one data center or
a couple data centers in one geography
and the idea of actually being closer to
their global end-users seemed like a
nice to have but I don't know how I'm
gonna do it
I don't know who to rely on I don't know
how to contract with them I don't speak
the language in some cases it just seems
like it's not gonna be easy to do and so
most don't but in the cloud the game
changes you can have your application in
any one of the nine regions AWS has all
over the world and that means you can
provide a lower latency experience for
your customers which is a much better
and user customer experience so in
summarizing the benefits the main
benefits why people are moving so fast
it's that they get to change capital
expense for variable expense pay a lower
variable expense and they can do on
their own they don't have to guess on
capacity they can move quicker which
enables a lot more innovation they get
to spend their scarce SDE resource on
projects to move the business forward
and they can go global with their
application presence in minutes
